article.paragraph: File:Taiko Tsukiji Honganji Festival.webmthumbrightThis ''kumi-daiko'' performance at theTsukiji Hongan-jiFestival involves several performers switching between ''ch-daiko''. Performers lean toward and away from the drum by adjusting the degree of bend in their left knee.alt=Video of taiko performers at the Tsukiji Hongan-ji FestivalNihongo3[[wikt:太鼓|太鼓]]'''Taiko'''are a broad range ofTraditional Japanese musical instrumentsJapanesepercussioninstruments. InJapanese languageJapanese, the term refers to any kind of drum, but outside Japan, it is used to refer to any of the various Japanese drums callednihongo4''wadaiko''和太鼓"Japanese drums"and to the form of ensemble taiko drumming more specifically callednihongo4''kumi-daiko''組太鼓"set of drums". The process of constructing taiko varies between manufacturers, and preparation of both the drum body and skin can take several years depending on methodology.

Taiko have a mythological origin inJapanese folklore, but historical records suggest that taiko were introduced to Japan through Korean and Chinese cultural influence as early as the 6th century CE. Some taiko are similar to instruments originating from India. Archaeological evidence also supports that taiko were present in Japan during the 6th century in theKofun period. Their function has varied through history, ranging from communication, military action, theatrical accompaniment, and religious ceremony to both festival and concert performances. In modern times, taiko have also played a central role in social movements for minorities both within and outside Japan.

Kumi-daikoperformance, characterized by an ensemble playing on different drums, was developed in 1951 through the work ofDaihachi Oguchiand has continued with groups such asKodo (taiko group)Kodo. Other performance styles, such ashachij-daiko, have also emerged from specific communities in Japan.Kumi-daikoperformance groups are active not only in Japan, but also in the United States, Australia, Canada, and Brazil. Taiko performance consists of many components in technical rhythm,kataform,drum stickstickgrip, clothing, and theinstrumentation (music)particular instrumentation. Ensembles typically use different types of barrel-shapednagad-daikoas well as smallershime-daiko. Many groups accompany the drums with vocals, strings, and woodwind instruments.TOC limit3
article.heading: History
Origin
article.paragraph: File:ThreeHaniwa.jpgthumbrightHaniwa, dated to the 6th century CE. The left and right depict two drum performers. The statue on the left, depicted using a stick on a barrel-shaped drum, represents the earliest evidence of taiko usage in Japan.alt=Three clay figures called haniwa, two of which depict figures playing drums.The origin of the instruments is unclear, though there have been many suggestions. Historical accounts, of which the earliest date from 588 CE, note that young Japanese men traveled to Korea to study theKakko (instrument)kakko, a drum that originated inSouth China. This study and appropriation of Chinese instruments may have influenced the emergence of taiko.sfnBlades1992122–123Certain court music styles, especiallygigakuandgagaku, arrived in Japan through both Korea and China.sfnNelson200736, 39sfnSchuller1989202In both traditions, dancers were accompanied by several instruments that included drums similar to taiko.sfnSchuller1989202sfnCossío2001179Certain percussive patterns and terminology intogaku, an early dance and music style in Japan, in addition to physical features of the kakko, also reflect influence from both China and India on drum use in gagaku performance.sfnBender201226sfnHarich-Schneider1973108, 110

Archaeological evidence shows that taiko were used in Japan as early as the 6th century CE,cite webMusic Festival at the Museumhttp://www.tnm.jp/modules/r_free_page/index.php?idTokyo National Museum24 August 2013during the latter part of theKofun period, and were likely used for communication and in festivals and other rituals.sfnDean2012122This evidence was substantiated by the discovery ofhaniwastatues in theSawa District, GunmaSawa DistrictofGunma Prefecture. Two of these figures are depicted playing drums;sfnDean2012122one of them, wearing skins, is equipped with a barrel-shaped drum hung from his shoulder and uses a stick to play the drum at hip height.sfnmDean2012122Varian201321cite webOchiMegumiWhat The Haniwa Have to Say About Taiko's Roots: The History of Taikohttp://www.taiko.com/taiko_resource/history/haniwa_ochi.htmlRolling Thunder27 December 2014This statue is titled "Man Beating the Taiko" and is considered the oldest evidence of taiko performance in Japan.sfnVarian201321Similarities between the playing style demonstrated by this haniwa and known music traditions in Korea and China further suggest influences from these regions.sfnVarian201321

TheNihon Shoki, the second oldest book of Japanese classical history, contains a mythological story describing the origin of taiko. The myth tells howAmaterasu, who had sealed herself inside a cave in anger, was beckoned out by an elder goddessAme-no-Uzume-no-MikotoAme-no-Uzumewhen others had failed. Ame-no-Uzume accomplished this by emptying out a barrel ofsakeand dancing furiously on top of it. Historians regard her performance as the mythological creation of taiko music.sfnmMinor200337–39Izumi200137–39Raz198319
article.heading: Use in warfare
article.paragraph: File:Adolfo Farsari - Dancing Girl Playing Taiko.JPGthumbrightHand-colored print of a woman playing a ''shime-daiko'', circa 1885alt=refer to captionIn feudal Japan, taiko were often used to motivate troops, call out orders or announcements, and set a marching pace; marches were usually set to six paces per beat of the drum.sfnTurnbull200837sfnTurnbull201227–28During the 16th-centurySengoku periodWarring States period, specific drum calls were used to communicate orders for retreating and advancing.sfnTurnbull201227Other rhythms and techniques were detailed in period texts. According to the war chronicleGunji Yosh, nine sets of five beats would summon an ally to battle, while nine sets of three beats, sped up three or four times, was the call to advance and pursue an enemy.sfnTurnbull200849Folklore from the 16th century on the legendary 6th-centuryEmperor Keitaioffers a story that he obtained a large drum from China, which he namednihongo4''Senjin-daiko''線陣太鼓"front drum".sfnGould199812The Emperor was thought to have used it to both encourage his own army and intimidate his enemies.sfnGould199812
article.heading: In traditional settings
article.paragraph: Taiko have been incorporated in Japanese theatre for rhythmic needs, general atmosphere, and in certain settings decoration. In thekabukiplayThe Tale of Shiroishi and the Taihei Chronicles, scenes in theYkakupleasure quartersare accompanied by taiko to create dramatic tension.sfnBrandonLeiter200286Nohtheatre also feature taikosfnMiki2008176sfnMalm2000286-288where performance consists of highly specific rhythmic patterns. Thenihongo4''Konparu''金春流school of drumming, for example, contains 65 basic patterns in addition to 25 special patterns; these patterns are categorized in several classes.sfnMalm196075–78Differences between these patterns include changes intempo,accent (music)accent,dynamics (music)dynamics,pitch (music)pitch, and function in the theatrical performance. Patterns are also often connected together in progressions.sfnMalm196075–78

Taiko continue to be used in a classical music tradition, gagaku, typically performed at theTokyo Imperial Palacein addition to local temples and shrines.sfnMalm2000101-102In gagaku, one component of the art form is traditional dance, which is guided in part by the rhythm set by the taiko.sfnMalm2000103Taiko have played an important role in many local festivals across Japan.cite webKenny Endo: Connecting to Heritage through Musichttp://www.janm.org/exhibits/bigdrum/interviews/endo.phpBig Drum[[Japanese American National Museum]]7 November 2013They are also used to accompany religious ritual music. Inkagura, which generically describes music and dances stemming fromShintopractices, taiko frequently appear alongside other performers during local festivals. In Buddhist traditions, taiko are used for ritual dances that are a part of theBon Festival.sfnMiki2008180sfnBender2012110Taiko, along with other instruments, are featured atop towers that are adorned with red-and-white cloth and serve to provide rhythms for the dancers who are encircled around the performers.sfnMalm200077
article.heading: Kumi-daiko
article.paragraph: See alsoDaihachi OguchiOndekozaKodo (taiko group)File:TaikoDrummersAichiJapan.jpgthumbleftA ''kumi-daiko'' group performing inAichi, Japanwearinghachimakialt=refer to captionIn addition to the instruments, the termtaikoalso refers to the performance itself,sfnKonagaya2005134sfnIngram200471and commonly to one style calledkumi-daiko, or ensemble-style playing (as opposed to festival performances, rituals, or theatrical use of the drums).sfnMillerShahriari2014146sfnPowell 2012aKumi-daikowas developed byDaihachi Oguchiin 1951.sfnMillerShahriari2014146sfnVarian200533He is considered a master performer and helped transform taiko performance from its roots in traditional settings in festivals and shrines.cite newsDaihachi Oguchi, 84, Japanese Drummer, Dieshttp://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/28/arts/music/28oguchi.html?_r21 August 2013[[The New York Times]]28 June 2008[[Associated Press]]Oguchi was trained as a jazz musician inNagano, and at one point, a relative gave him an old piece of written taiko music.sfnAlves2012312Unable to read the traditional and esoteric notation,sfnAlves2012312Oguchi found help to transcribe the piece, and on his own added rhythms and transformed the work to accommodate multiple taiko players on different-sized instruments.sfnVarian200528Each instrument served a specific purpose that established present-day conventions inkumi-daikoperformance.sfnVarian200529sfnBender201251

Oguchi's ensemble,Osuwa Daiko, incorporated these alterations and other drums into their performances. They also devised novel pieces that were intended for non-religious performances.sfnAlves2012312Several other groups emerged in Japan through the 1950s and 1960s.Oedo Sukeroku Daikowas formed inTokyoin 1959 underSeid Kobayashi,sfnPowell 2012b125and has been referred to as the first taiko group who toured professionally.sfnWong2004204Globally,kumi-daikoperformance became more visible during the1964 Summer Olympicsin Tokyo, when it was featured during the Festival of Arts event.sfnVarian200528–29

Kumi-daikowas also developed through the leadership ofnihongo4[[Den Tagayasu]]田耕Den Tagayasu, who gathered young men who were willing to devote their entire lifestyle to taiko playing and took them toSado Islandfor trainingsfnVarian200529sfnWaldVartoogian2007251where Den and his family had settled in 1968.sfnKonagaya200565Den chose the island based on a desire to reinvigorate the folk arts in Japan, particularly taiko; he became inspired by a drumming tradition unique to Sado callednihongo4''ondeko''鬼太鼓"demon drumming" in Sado dialectthat required considerable strength to play well.sfnKonagaya200564–65Den called the group "Za Ondekoza" orOndekozafor short, and implemented a rigorous set of exercises for its members including long-distance running.sfnVarian200528sfnWaldVartoogian2007251In 1975, Ondekoza was the first taiko group to tour in the United States. Their first performance occurred just after the group finished running theBoston Marathonwhile wearing their traditional uniforms.sfnKonagaya2005149sfnMcLeod2013171In 1981, some members of Ondekoza split from Den and formed another group calledKodo (taiko group)Kodounder the leadership ofEitetsu Hayashi.sfnHoover201198Kodo continued to use Sado Island for rigorous training and communal living, and went on to popularize taiko through frequent touring and collaborations with other musical performers.sfnLacashire201114Kodo is one of the most recognized taiko groups both in Japancite newsAritaErikoKodo drum troupe marks 25 years of Earth Celebrationhttp://www.japantimes.co.jp/culture/2012/08/17/events/events-outside-tokyo/kodo-drum-troupe-marks-25-years-of-earth-celebration/#.VIjBF3sZfCs10 December 2014[[The Japan Times]]17 August 2012cite newsMatsumotoJohnGospel and Drums According to Kodo : Music: Southland choir members will blend their talents with rhythms of Japanese ensemble in non-traditional concert on Sado Island in Japan.http://articles.latimes.com/1990-08-17/entertainment/ca-670_1_gospel-music10 December 2014[[Los Angeles Times]]17 August 1990and worldwide.sfnBender201272bulleted listBarr|first1Keogh|first1Soh Daiko, the Fine Art of Japanese Drumming|url

Estimates of the number of taiko groups in Japan vary up to 5000 active in Japan,sfnVarian200517but more conservative assessments place the number closer to 800 based on membership in the Nippon Taiko Foundation, the largest national organization of taiko groups.sfnBender20123Some pieces that have emerged from earlykumi-daikogroups that continue to be performed includeYatai-bayashifrom Ondekoza,sfnBender201274nihongo4''Isami-goma''勇み駒"galloping horse"from Osuwa Daiko,sfnBender201287andnihongo4''Zoku''族"tribe"from Kodo.sfnBender2012102
article.heading: Categorization

tablerow.tablecell: tsukeshime-daikounbulleted list namitsuke nichō-gakke anchō-gakke yonchō-gakke gochō-gakke

article.paragraph: Taiko have been developed into a broad range ofpercussion instrumentsthat are used in bothMusic of JapanJapanese folk and classicalmusical traditions. An early classification system based on shape and tension was advanced byFrancis Taylor Piggottin 1909.sfnPiggott1971191–203Taiko are generally classified based on the construction process, or the specific context in which the drum is used,sfnGould199812but some are not classified, such as the toyden-den daiko.sfnKakehiTamoriSchourup1996251

With few exceptions, taiko have a drum shell with heads on both sides of the body, and a sealed resonating cavity.sfnGould199812The head may be fastened to the shell using a number of different systems, such as using ropes.sfnGould199812Taiko may be either tunable or non-tunable depending on the system used.sfnTusler200360

Taiko are categorized into three types based on construction process.By-uchi-daikoare constructed with thedrumheadnailed to the body.sfnGould199812Shime-daikoare classically constructed with the skin placed over iron or steel rings, which are then tightened with ropes.sfnVarian201357Contemporaryshime-daikoare tensioned usingScrewboltsorturnbucklessystems attached to the drum body.sfnGould199812sfnMiki2008177Tsuzumiare also rope-tensioned drums, but have a distinct hourglass shape and their skins are made using deerskin.sfnVarian201357

By-uchi-daikowere historically made only using a single piece of wood;sfnCarlsen2009130–131they continue to be made in this manner, but are also constructed from staves of wood.sfnGould199812Larger drums can be made using a single piece of wood, but at a much greater cost due to the difficulty in finding appropriate trees.sfnGould199812The preferred wood is theZelkova serrataJapanese zelkovaorkeyaki,sfnAmmer2004420but a number of other woods, and evenwine barrels, have been used to create taiko.sfnAmmer2004420By-uchi-daikocannot be tuned.sfnTusler200360

The typicalby-uchi-daikois thenagad-daiko,cite webDrums and Other Instrumentshttp://www.shumeitaiko.org/drums.htmlThe Shumei Taiko Ensemble26 February 2015an elongated drum that is roughly shaped like a wine barrel.sfnVarian201355Nagad-daikoare available in a variety of sizes, and their head diameter is traditionally measured inshaku (unit)shaku(units of roughly 30 cm). Head diameters range fromconvert1to6shakucm in.nihongo4''Ko-daiko''小太鼓are the smallest of these drums and are usually aboutconvert1shakucm inin diameter.sfnVarian201355Thech-daikois a medium-sizednagad-daikoranging fromconvert1.6to2.8shakucm in,and weighing aboutconvert27kglbs.sfnVarian201355nihongo4''Ō-daiko''大太鼓vary in size, and are often as large asconvert6shakucm inin diameter.sfnTitonFujie2005184Some-daikoare difficult to move due to their size, and therefore permanently remain inside the performance space, such as temple or shrine.cite webHeartbeat of Drumshttps://www.classicaltv.com/the-informer/heartbeat-of-drumsClassical TV15 February 2015-daikomeans "large drum" and for a given ensemble, the term refers to their largest drum.sfnTitonFujie2005184The other type ofby-uchi-daikois called anihongo4''hira-daiko''平太鼓"flat drum"and describes any drum constructed such that the head diameter is greater than the length of the body.sfnVarian2013121–122

Shime-daikoare a set of smaller, roughly-snare drumsized instrument that are tunable.sfnVarian201357The tensioning system usually consists of hemp cords or rope, but bolt or turnbuckle systems have been used as well.sfnMiki2008177sfnVarian2013130nihongo4''Nagauta shime-daiko''長唄締め太鼓, sometimes referred to as "taiko" in the context of theater, have thinner heads than other kinds of shime-daiko.sfnVarian2013130The head includes a patch of deerskin is placed in the center, and in performance, drum strokes are generally restricted to this area.sfnMiki2008177Thenihongo4''tsukeshime-daiko''付け締め太鼓is a heavier type ofshime-daiko.sfnVarian201357They are available in sizes 15, and are named according to their number:namitsuke (1),nich-gakke (2),sanch-gakke (3),yonch-gakke (4), andgoch-gakke (5).sfnVarian2013119, 126Thenamitsukehas the thinnest skins and the shortest body in terms of height; thickness and tension of skins, as well as body height, increase toward thegoch-gakke.sfnVarian2013119The head diameters of allshime-daikosizes are aroundconvert27cmin1on.sfnMiki2008177

article.paragraph: Oked-daikoor simplyoked, are a type ofshime-daikothat are stave-constructed using narrower strips of wood,sfnGould199812cite webTaiko in the United Stateshttp://janmstore.com/taikointheus.htmlTaiko in the United StatesJapanese American National Museum20 August 2013https://web.archive.org/web/20141030005957/http://janmstore.com/taikointheus.html30 October 2014have a tube-shaped frame. Like othershime-daiko, drum heads are attached by metal hoops and fastened by rope or cords.sfnMiki2008181Okedcan be played using the same drumsticks (calledbachi) asshime-daiko, but can also be hand-played.sfnMiki2008181Okedcome in short- and long-bodied types.

Tsuzumiare a class of hourglass-shaped drums. The drum body is shaped on a spool and the inner body carved by hand.sfnBlades1992126Their skins can be made from cowhide, horsehide, or deerskin.sfnBender201228While the-tsuzumiskins are made from cowhide,ko-tsuzumiare made from horsehide. While some classifytsuzumias a type of taiko,sfnBender201228sfnVarian201357others have described them as a drum entirely separate from taiko.sfnBlades1992124sfnMiki2008156

Taiko can also be categorized by the context in which they are used. Themiya-daiko, for instance, is constructed in the same manner as otherby-uchi-daiko, but is distinguished by an ornamental stand and is used for ceremonial purposes atBuddhist temples in JapanBuddhist temples.sfnGould199813sfnYoon2001420Thenihongo4''Sumō-daiko''相撲太鼓(ako-daiko) andnihongo4''sairei-nagadō''祭礼長胴(anagad-daikowith a cigar-shaped body) are used insumoand festivals respectively.sfnVarian2013129, 131

File:Yashima Gakutei - A woman playing a large suspended drum (tsuridaiko) A set of five prints for the Hisakataya poetry c... - Google Art Project.jpgthumbrightABlock printing in Japanwoodprint blockbyYashima Gakuteiillustrating a woman playing a ''tsuri-daiko''alt=refer to captionSeveral drums, categorized asgagakki, are used in the Japanese theatrical form,gagaku.sfnMiki2008169The lead instrument of the ensemble is thekakko (instrument)kakko,sfnMalm2000104which is a smallershime-daikowith heads made of deerskin, and is placed horizontally on a stand during performance.sfnMalm2000104Atsuzumi, called thesan-no-tsuzumiis another small drum in gagaku that is placed horizontally and struck with a thin stick.sfnBender201227nihongo4''Dadaiko''鼉太鼓are the largest drums of the ensemble,sfnMalm2000335and have heads that are aboutconvert127cmin0onin diameter. During performance, the drum is placed on a tall pedestals and surrounded by a rim decoratively painted with flames and adorned with mystical figures such aswyverns.sfnBlades1992124-125Dadaikoare played while standing,sfnBlades1992123and are usually only played on theBeat (music)#Downbeatdownbeatof the music.sfnMiki2008169Thenihongo4''[[tsuri-daiko]]''釣太鼓"suspended drum"is a smaller drum that produces a lower sound, its head measuring aboutconvert55cmin0onin diameter.sfnMiki2008171It is used in ensembles that accompanybugaku, a traditional dance performed at theTokyo Imperial Palaceand in religious contexts.sfnBlades1992122–123Tsuri-daikoare suspended on a small stand, and are played sitting down.sfnMiki2008171Tsuri-daikoperformers typically use shorter mallets covered in leather knobs instead ofbachi.sfnBlades1992122–123They can be played simultaneously by two performers; while one performer plays on the head, another performer uses bachi on the body of the drum.sfnBlades1992122–123

The larger-tsuzumiand smallerko-tsuzumiare used in the opening and dances ofNoh theater.sfnMalm2000137, 142Both drums are struck using the fingers; players can also adjust pitch by manually applying pressure to the ropes on the drum.sfnVarian201358The color of the cords of these drums also indicates the skill of the musician: Orange and red for amateur players, light blue for performers with expertise, andlilac (color)lilacfor masters of the instrument.sfnBlades1992127Nagauta-shime daikooruta daikoare also featured in Noh performance.sfnBlades1992125sfnRoth2002161

Many taiko in Noh are also featured inkabukiperformance and are used in a similar manner.sfnMalm196374–77In addition to the-tsuzumi,ko-tsuzumi, andnagauta-shime daiko,sfnMalm196375Kabuki performances make use of the larger-daikooffstage to help set the atmosphere for different scenes.sfnBrandonLeiter2002153,363
article.heading: Construction
Process
article.paragraph: Taiko construction has several stages, including making and shaping of the drum body (or shell), preparing the drum skin, and tuning the skin to the drumhead. Variations in the construction process often occur in the latter two parts of this process.sfnVarian201353Historically,by-uchi-daikowere crafted fromtrunk (botany)trunksof the Japanese zelkova tree that were dried out over years, using techniques to preventwood splittingsplitting. A master carpenter then carved out the rough shape of the drum body with a chisel; the texture of the wood after carving softened the tone of the drum.sfnVarian201353sfnBender201235In contemporary times, taiko are carved out on a largelatheusing wood stavessfnCarlsen2009130–131or logs that can be shaped to fit drum bodies of various sizes.sfnVarian201354Drumheads can be left to air-dry over a period of years,sfnGould199817but some companies use large, smoke-filled warehouses to hasten the drying process.sfnBender201235After drying is complete, the inside of the drum is worked with a deep-grooved chisel and sanded.sfnGould199817Lastly, handles are placed onto the drum. These are used to carry smaller drums and they serve an ornamental purpose for larger drums.sfnGould199818

File:Taiko drum manufacturing.jpgthumbleftTaiko drum manufacturing display in theOsaka Human Rights Museumalt=A display at the Osaka Human Rights Museum depicting two workers, wielding large mallets, in the process of applying appropriate tension to a taiko.Thedrum skinskinsor heads of taiko are generally made fromcowhidefromHolstein cattleHolstein cowsaged about three or four years. Skins also come fromhorses, andbullskin is preferred for larger drums.sfnMalm196075–78sfnVarian201353Thinner skins are preferred for smaller taiko, and thicker skins are used for larger ones.sfnBender201236On some drumheads, a patch of deer skin placed in the center serves as the target for many strokes during performance.sfnMalm196075–78Before fitting it to the drum body the hair is removed from the hide by soaking it in a river or stream for about a month; winter months are preferred as colder temperatures better facilitate hair removal.sfnGould199818To stretch the skin over the drum properly, one process requires the body to be held on a platform with severalhydraulic jacksunderneath it. The edges of the cowhide are secured to an apparatus below the jacks, and the jacks stretch the skin incrementally to precisely apply tension across the drumhead.sfnCarlsen2009131Other forms of stretching use rope or cords with woodendowelsor an iron wheel to create appropriate tension.sfnGould199818sfnCangia201336Small tension adjustments can be made during this process using small pieces of bamboo that twist around the ropes.sfnGould199818Particularly large drumheads are sometimes stretched by having several workers, clad in stockings, hop rhythmically atop it, forming a circle along the edge. After the skin has dried, tacks, calledby, are added to the appropriate drums to secure it;ch-daikorequire about 300 of them for each side.sfnGould199819After the body and skin have been finished, excess hide is cut off and the drum can be stained as needed.sfnGould199819
article.heading: Drum makers
article.paragraph: Several companies specialize in the production of taiko. One such company that created drums exclusively for theEmperor of Japan,Miyamoto Unosuke Shotenin Tokyo, has been making taiko since 1861.sfnVarian201353TheAsano Taiko Corporationis another major taiko-producing organization, and has been producing taiko for over 400 years.sfnBender201234–35cite newsDretzkaGaryCaroMarkHow `An Alan Smithee Film' Became An Alan Smithee Filmhttp://articles.chicagotribune.com/1998-03-01/news/9803010298_1_cinergi-pictures-arthur-hiller-ben-myron/229 November 2014[[Chicago Tribune]]1 March 1998The family-owned business started inMatt, Ishikawa, and, aside from military equipment, made taiko for Noh theater and later expanded to creating instruments for festivals during theMeiji period. Asano currently maintains an entire complex of large buildings referred to as Asano Taiko Village,sfnBender201234–35and the company reports producing up to 8000 drums each year.cite webja:株式会社浅野太鼓楽器店http://www.asano.jp/village/profile/asanotaiko/Asano.jpAsano Taiko Corporation23 February 2015https://web.archive.org/web/20131109033131/http://www.asano.jp/village/profile/asanotaiko/9 November 2013JapaneseAs of 2012, there is approximately one major taiko production company inPrefectures of Japaneach prefecture of Japan, with some regions having several companies.sfnBender201238Of the manufacturers in Naniwa, Taikoya Matab is one of the most successful and is thought to have brought considerable recognition to the community and attracted many drum makers there.sfnBender201244Umetsu Daiko, a company that operates inHakata-ku, FukuokaHakata, has been producing taiko since 1821.sfnGould199817
article.heading: Performance
article.paragraph: Taiko performance styles vary widely across groups in terms of the number of performers, repertoire, instrument choices, and stage techniques.sfnBender201219, 70Nevertheless, a number of early groups have had broad influence on the tradition. For instance, many pieces developed by Ondekoza and Kodo are considered standard in many taiko groups.sfnBender201260
article.heading: Form
article.paragraph: Katais a term used to describe the posture and movement associated with taiko performance.sfnPowell 2012asfnTusler200373–74The term is used in martial arts in a similar way: for example, both traditions include the idea that thehara (tanden)harais the center of being.sfnPowell 2012asfnVarian201389Author Sean Bender argues that kata is the primary feature that distinguishes different taiko groups from one another, and is a key factor in judging the quality of performance.sfnBender201210For this reason, many practice rooms intended for taiko contain mirrors to provide visual feedback to players.sfnBender2012122An important part of kata in taiko is keeping the body stabilized while performing, and can be accomplished by keeping a wide, low stance with the legs, with the left knee bent over the toes and keeping the right leg straight.sfnPowell 2012asfnVarian201394It is important for that the hips face the drum and the shoulders be relaxed.sfnVarian201394Some teachers note a tendency to rely on the upper body while playing, and emphasize the importance of the holistic use of the body during performance.sfnBender2005201

Some groups in Japan, particularly those active in Tokyo, also emphasize the importance of the lively and spiritedIki (aesthetics)ikiaesthetic.sfnBender200558In taiko, it refers to very specific kinds of movement while performing that evoke the sophistication stemming from the mercantile and artisan classes active during theEdo period(16031868).sfnBender200558

File:Taikos bachi.jpgthumbright''Bachi'' are sticks used specifically for taiko performance, and can be slightly thicker than typicaldrum sticks.alt=Different types of drum sticks for taiko, called bachi, are displayed flat on a surface.The sticks for playing taiko are calledbachi, and are made in various sizes and from different kinds of wood such asQuercus albawhite oak,bamboo, andJapanese magnolia.sfnVarian201359Bachiare also held in a number of different styles.sfnVarian201392Inkumi-daiko, it is common for a player to hold their sticks in a relaxed manner between the V-shape of the index finger and thumb, which points to the player.sfnVarian201392There are other grips that allow performers to play much more technically difficult rhythms, such as theshimegrip, which is similar to amatched grip: thebachiare gripped at the back end, and thefulcrum (drumming)fulcrumrests between the performer's index finger and thumb, while the other fingers remain relaxed and slightly curled around the stick.cite journalModern PercussionistN/A31986Modern Drummer Publications, Inc.2811672313

Performance in some groups is also guided by principles based onZen Buddhism. For instance, among other concepts, the San Francisco Taiko Dojo is guided bynihongo4''rei''礼emphasizing communication, respect, and harmony.sfnWong200484The way thebachiare held can also be significant; for some groups,bachirepresent a spiritual link between the body and the sky.sfnPowell 2012b''[https://books.google.com/books?idSome physical parts of taiko, like the drum body, its skin, and the tacks also hold symbolic significance in Buddhism.sfnPowell 2012b''[https://books.google.com/books?id
article.heading: Instrumentation

link.part: Several drummers perform a traditional pattern on a taiko drum at a summer festival in Japan.

article.paragraph: Kumi-daikogroups consist primarily of percussive instruments where each of the drums plays a specific role. Of the different kinds of taiko, the most common in groups is thenagad-daiko.sfnDean2012125Ch-daikoare common in taiko groupssfnPowell 2012aand represent the main rhythm of the group, whereasshime-daikoset and change tempo.sfnVarian201355-daikoprovide a steady, underlying pulsesfnAlves2012312and serve as a counter-rhythm to the other parts.sfnTusler200370, 72It is common for performances to begin with asingle stroke rollcalled anNihongo4oroshi颪"wind blowing down from mountains".sfnPowell 2012a[https://books.google.com/books?idThe player starts slowly, leaving considerable space between strikes, gradually shortening the interval between hits, until the drummer is playing a rapid roll of hits.sfnPowell 2012a[https://books.google.com/books?idOroshi are also played as a part of theatrical performance, such as in Noh theater.sfnMalm196075–78

Drums are not the only instruments played in the ensemble; other Japanese instruments are also used. Other kinds of percussion instruments include thenihongo4''atarigane''当り鉦, a hand-sized gong played with a small mallet.sfnBender201232In kabuki, theshamisen, aplucked string instrument, often accompanies taiko during the theatrical performance.sfnBender201229Kumi-daikoperformances can also feature woodwinds such as theshakuhachisfnNelson2007287and theshinobue.sfnNelson2007288sfnForss2010597

Voiced calls or shouts calledkakegoeandkiaiare also common in taiko performance.sfnNelson2007139sfnVarian201362They are used as encouragement to other players or cues for transition or change in dynamics such as an increase in tempo.sfnBender201229, 51In contrast, the philosophical concept ofMa (negative space)ma, which superficially describes the space between drum strikes, is also important in shaping rhythmic phrases and creating appropriate contrast.sfnVarian201389–90, 125
article.heading: Clothing
article.paragraph: There is a wide variety of traditional clothing that players wear during taiko performance. Common in manykumi-daikogroups is the use of thehappi, a decorative, thin-fabric coat, and traditional headbands calledhachimaki.sfnKonagaya2005150Tabi,nihongo4''momohiki''もも引き"loose-fitting pants", andnihongo4''haragake''腹掛け"working aprons"are also typical.sfnKonagaya2010645During his time with the group Ondekoza, Eitetsu Hayashi suggested that a loincloth called afundoshibe worn when performing for French fashion designerPierre Cardin, who saw Ondekoza perform for him in 1975.cite journalN/AAsian Music: Journal of the Society for Asian Music402009Society for Asian Music10853164383The Japanese group Kodo has sometimes worn fundoshi for its performances.sfnKonagaya2005151
article.heading: Education
article.paragraph: Taiko performance is generally taught orally and through demonstration.sfnBender2012115sfnMalm198624Historically, general patterns for taiko were written down, such as in the 1512 encyclopedia called theTaigensho,sfnHarich-Schneider1973394but written scores for taiko pieces are generally unavailable. One reason for the adherence to an oral tradition is that, from group to group, the rhythmic patterns in a given piece are often performed differently.sfnMalm1986202Furthermore, ethnomusicologist William P. Malm observed that Japanese players within a group could not usefully predict one another using written notation, and instead did so through listening.sfnMalm198624–25In Japan, printed parts are not used during lessons.sfnHarich-Schneider1973394

Orally, patterns ofonomatopoeiacalledkuchi shgaare taught from teacher to student that convey the rhythm andtimbreof drum strikes for a particular piece.sfnTusler200390, 271sfnVarian201390For example,nihongo4''don''どんrepresents a single strike to the center of the drum,sfnVarian201390where asnihongo4''do-ko''どこrepresents two successive strikes, first by the right and then the left, and lasts the same amount of time as onedonstrike.sfnBender2012139Some taiko pieces, such asYatai-bayashi, include patterns that are difficult to represent inList of musical symbolsWestern musical notation.sfnBender2012139The exact words used can also differ from region to region.sfnBender2012139

More recently, Japanese publications have emerged in an attempt to standardize taiko performance. TheNippon Taiko Foundationwas formed in 1979; its primary goals were to foster good relations among taiko groups in Japan and to both publicize and teach how to perform taiko.sfnBender2012182sfnCangia2013129Daihachi Oguchi, the leader of the Foundation, wroteJapan Taikowith other teachers in 1994 out of concern that correct form in performance would degrade over time.sfnBender2012183The instructional publication described the different drums used inkumi-daikoperformance, methods of gripping, correct form, and suggestions on instrumentation. The book also contains practice exercises and transcribed pieces from Oguchi's group, Osuwa Daiko. While there were similar textbooks published before 1994, this publication had much more visibility due to the Foundation's scope.sfnBender2012184

The system of fundamentalsJapan Taikoput forward was not widely adopted because taiko performance varied substantially across Japan. An updated 2001 publication from the Foundation, called thenihongo4''Nihon Taiko Kyōhon''日本太鼓教本"Japan Taiko Textbook", describes regional variations that depart from the main techniques taught in the textbook. The creators of the text maintained that mastering a set of prescribed basics should be compatible with learning local traditions.sfnBender2012185–187
article.heading: Regional styles
article.paragraph: Aside fromkumi-daikoperformance, a number of folk traditions that use taiko have been recognized in different regions in Japan. Some of these includenihongo4''ondeko''鬼太鼓"demon drumming"fromSado, NiigataSado Island,Interlanguage linkjagion-daiko小倉祇園太鼓from the town ofKokura, andInterlanguage linkjasansa-odori盛岡さんさ踊りfromIwate Prefecture.sfnBender2012225
article.heading: Eisa
article.paragraph: File:An eisa folk dancing troupe performs at the 2010 Okinawa International Carnival Nov 101127-F-HZ730-008.jpgthumbEisa are folk dances from Okinawa that involve the use of taiko while dancing.alt=An eisa folk dancing troupe performs at night at the 2010 Okinawa International Carnival.mainEisa (dance)A variety of folk dances originating fromOkinawa, known collectively asEisa (dance)eisa, often make use of the taiko.sfnTerada2013234Some performers use drums while dancing, and generally speaking, perform in one of two styles:sfnKumada2011193–244groups on theUruma, Okinawa#Yokatsu IslandsYokatsu Peninsulaand on Hamahiga Island use small, single-sided drums callednihongo4''pāranku''パーランクwhereas groups nearOkinawa, Okinawathe city of Okinawagenerally useshime-daiko.sfnTerada2013234sfnKobayashi199836–40Use ofshime-daikooverprankuhas spread throughout the island, and is considered the dominant style.sfnKobayashi199836–40Smallnagad-daiko, referred to as-daikowithin the tradition, are also usedsfnCangia2013149and are worn in front of the performer.sfnBender2012210These drum dances are not limited to Okinawa and have appeared in places containing Okinawan communities such as inSo Paulo,Hawaii, and large cities on theHonshuJapanese mainland.sfnTerada2013235
article.heading: Hachij-daiko
article.paragraph: File:Hachijo taiko 2007-03-21-alt.jpgthumbleftHachij-daiko is a music tradition involving two players on a single drum.alt=Two women wearing kimonos perform traditional Hachij-daiko.nihongo4''Hachijō-daiko''八丈太鼓trans. "Hachijō-style taiko"is a taiko tradition originating on the island ofHachij-jima.sfnAlaszewska2008171Two styles ofHachij-daikoemerged and have been popularized among residents: an older tradition based on a historical account, and a newer tradition influenced by mainland groups and practiced by the majority of the islanders.sfnAlaszewska2008171

TheHachij-daikotradition was documented as early as 1849 based on a journal kept by an exile namedKakuso Kizan. He mentioned some of its unique features, such as "a taiko is suspended from a tree while women and children gathered around", and observed that a player used either side of the drum while performing.sfnAlaszewska20082Illustrations from Kizan's journal show features ofHachij-daiko. These illustrations also featured women performing, which is unusual as taiko performance elsewhere during this period was typically reserved for men. Teachers of the tradition have noted that the majority of its performers were women; one estimate asserts that female performers outnumbered males by three to one.sfnAlaszewska20083

File:Hachijo-style taiko performance.webmthumbrightA performance in Hachij-daiko style. On the upright drum, the ''uwa-byshi'' (left) plays more complex rhythms while the ''shita-byshi'' (right) plays a consistent underlying rhythm.alt=refer to captionThe first style of Hachij-daiko is thought to descend directly from the style reported by Kizan. This style is calledKumaoji-daiko, named after its creator Okuyama Kumaoji, a central performer of the style.sfnAlaszewska20085Kumaoji-daikohas two players on a single drum, one of whom, called thenihongo4''shita-byōshi''下拍子"lower beat", provides the underlying beat.sfnAlaszewska20088The other player, called thenihongo4''uwa-byōshi''上拍子"upper beat", builds on this rhythmical foundation with unique and typically improvised rhythms.sfnAlaszewska20088sfnHonda1984931While there are specific types of underlying rhythms, the accompanying player is free to express an original musical beat.sfnAlaszewska20088Kumaoji-daikoalso features an unusual positioning for taiko: the drums are sometimes suspended from ropes,sfnAlaszewska20087and historically, sometimes drums were suspended from trees.sfnAlaszewska20082

The contemporary style ofHachij-daikois callednihongo4''shin-daiko''新太鼓"new taiko", which differs fromKumaoji-daikoin multiple ways. For instance, while the lead and accompanying roles are still present,shin-daikoperformances use larger drums exclusively on stands.sfnAlaszewska200814, 18–19Shin-daikoemphasizes a more powerful sound, and consequently, performers use larger bachi made out of stronger wood.sfnAlaszewska200819Looser clothing is worn byshin-daikoperformers compared tokimonoworn byKumaoji-daikoperformers; the looser clothing inshin-daikoallow performers to adopt more open stances and larger movements with the legs and arms.sfnAlaszewska200814, 19Rhythms used for the accompanyingshita-byshirole can also differ. One type of rhythm, calledykichi, consists of the following:clearFile:Yukichi.pngalt=Music notation indicating a drum rhythmcenter

This rhythm is found in both styles, but is always played faster inshin-daiko.sfnAlaszewska200814Another type of rhythm, calledhonbadaki, is unique toshin-daikoand also contains a song which is performed in standard Japanese.sfnAlaszewska200814
article.heading: Miyake-daiko
article.paragraph: nihongo4''Miyake-daiko''三宅太鼓trans. "Miyake-style taiko"is a style that has spread amongst groups through Kodo, and is formally known asnihongo4''Miyake-jima Kamitsuki mikoshi-daiko''三宅島神着神輿太鼓.sfnBender201298The wordmiyakecomes fromMiyake-jima, part of theIzu Islands, and the wordKamitsukirefers to the village where the tradition came from. Miyake-style taiko came out of performances fornihongo4''Gozu Tennō Sai''牛頭天王祭"Gozu Tennō Festival"a traditional festival held annually in July on Miyake Island since 1820 honoring the deityGozu Tenn.sfnIkeda1983275In this festival, players perform on taiko whileportable shrinesare carried around town.cite webOverviewhttp://www.miyaketaiko.com/en/overview/index.htmlMiyake Taiko20 August 2013The style itself is characterized in a number of ways. Anagad-daikois typically set low to the ground and played by two performers, one on each side; instead of sitting, performers stand and hold a stance that is also very low to the ground, almost to the point of kneeling.sfnBender201298–99
article.heading: Outside Japan
Australia
article.paragraph: Taiko groups in Australia began forming in the 1990s.sfnBloustein1999131The first group, called Ataru Taru Taiko, was formed in 1995 by Paulene Thomas, Harold Gent, and Kaomori Kamei.sfnBloustein1999166TaikOzwas later formed by percussionist Ian Cleworth andRiley Lee, a former Ondekoza member, and has been performing in Australia since 1997.sfnde Ferranti200780They are known for their work in generating interest in performing taiko among Australian audiences, such as by developing a complete education program with both formal and informal classes,sfnWebbSeddon2012762and have a strong fan base.sfnde Ferranti200791Cleworth and other members of the group have developed several original pieces.sfnde Ferranti200784
article.heading: Brazil

link.part: Performance of the composition "Zero" by Brazilian group Seiryu Daiko in Fukuoka, Japan
alt=Members of Brazilian group Seiryu Daiko performing on stage with a variety of taiko.

article.paragraph: The introduction ofkumi-daikoperformance in Brazil can be traced back to the 1970s and 1980s in So Paulo.sfnLorenz2007102Tangue Setsukofounded an eponymous taiko dojo and was Brazil's first taiko group;sfnLorenz2007102Setsuo Kinoshitalater formed the group Wadaiko Sho.sfnLorenz200726Brazilian groups have combined native andRhythm in Sub-Saharan AfricaAfrican drumming techniqueswith taiko performance. One such piece developed by Kinoshita is calledTaiko de Samba, which emphasizes both Brazilian and Japanese aesthetics in percussion traditions.sfnLorenz2007115, 130–139Taiko was also popularized in Brazil from 2002 through the work of Yukihisa Oda, a Japanese native who visited Brazil several times through theJapan International Cooperation Agency.cite webHorikawaHelderhttp://www.nippobrasil.com.br/especial/537.shtmlMatérias Especiais – Jornal NippoBrasilNippobrasil22 August 2013Portuguese

The Brazilian Association of Taiko (ABT) suggests that there are about 150 taiko groups in Brazil and that about 1015% of players are non-Japanese; Izumo Honda, coordinator of a large annual festival in So Paulo, estimated that about 60% of all taiko performers in Brazil are women.
article.heading: North America
article.paragraph: File:SohDaiko08.jpgthumbleftNew York-based groupSoh Daikowas one of the earlier ''kumi-daiko'' groups to form in the eastern United States.alt=Performers from the group Soh Daiko perform outdoors on various drums in front of an audience.Taiko emerged in the United States in the late 1960s. The first group,San Francisco Taiko Dojo, was formed in 1968 bySeiichi Tanaka, a postwar immigrant who studied taiko in Japan and brought the styles and teachings to the US.cite webSeiichi Tanakahttp://arts.gov/honors/heritage/fellows/seiichi-tanaka2001 NEA National Heritage Fellowships[[National Endowment for the Arts]]7 November 2013sfnKonagaya2005136–138A year later, a few members ofSenshin Buddhist Templein Los Angeles led by its minister Masao Kodani initiated another group calledKinnara Taiko.sfnKonagaya2005136, 144San Jose Taikolater formed in 1973 inJapantown, San Jose, underRoy HirabayashiRoyandPJ Hirabayashi.cite webRoy and PJ Hirabayashihttp://arts.gov/honors/heritage/fellows/roy-and-pj-hirabayashi2011 NEA National Heritage Fellowships[[National Endowment for the Arts]]20 October 2013sfnIzumi2006159Taiko started to branch out to the eastern US in the late 1970s.sfnKonagaya2005145This included formation ofDenver Taikoin 1976sfnKonagaya2005145andSoh DaikoinNew York Cityin 1979.cite newsDouglasMartinNew Yorkers & Co.; Banging the Drum Not So Slowlyhttp://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res11 November 2014[[The New York Times]]22 October 1995cite webGottfriedErikaGuide to the Soh Daiko Archive Records and Videotapeshttp://dlib.nyu.edu/findingaids/html/tamwag/tam_634/The Taminant Library & Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives11 November 2014Many of these early groups lacked the resources to equip each member with a drum and resorted to makeshift percussion materials such as rubber tires or creating taiko out of wine barrels.sfnKonagaya2005145

Japanese-Canadian taiko began in 1979 with Katari Taiko, and was inspired by the San Jose Taiko group.cite webHistoryhttp://www.vancouvertaiko.ca/history/Vancouver Taiko Society21 August 2013sfnNomura2005333Its early membership was predominantly female.sfnLi201155Katari Taiko and future groups were thought to represent an opportunity for younger, third-generationJapanese Canadiansto explore their roots, redevelop a sense of ethnic community, and expand taiko into other musical traditions.sfnIzumi200137–39

There are no official counts or estimates of the number of active taiko groups in the United States or Canada, as there is no governing body for taiko groups in either country. Unofficial estimates have been made. In 1989, there were as many as 30 groups in the US and Canada, seven of which were inCalifornia.cite newsTagashiraGailLocal Groups Share Taiko Drum Heritagehttp://articles.latimes.com/1989-02-03/entertainment/ca-2126_1_taiko-group12 April 2014[[Los Angeles Times]]3 February 1989One estimate suggested that around 120 groups were active in the US and Canada as of 2001, many of which could be traced to the San Francisco Taiko Dojo;cite webLiuTerryGo For Broke2001http://arts.gov/honors/heritage/fellows/seiichi-tanaka2001 NEA National Heritage ScholarshipsNational Endowment for the Arts24 August 2013later estimates in 2005 and 2006 suggested there were about 200 groups in the United States alone.sfnVarian200517sfnIzumi2006159

TheCirque du SoleilshowsMystre (Cirque du Soleil)Mystrein Las Vegascite newsPrzybysJohnEx-acrobat tells of soaring with Cirque du Soleil, helping others reach dreamshttp://www.reviewjournal.com/life/ex-acrobat-tells-soaring-cirque-du-soleil-helping-others-reach-dreams9 January 2015Las Vegas Review-JournalStephens Media31 March 2014andDralionhave featured taiko performance.cite newsRaineySarahCirque du Soleil: a day learning tricks at the circushttp://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/features/10858577/Cirque-du-Soleil-a-day-learning-tricks-at-the-circus.html9 January 2015[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]27 May 2014sfnKeene201118–19Taiko performance has also been featured in commercial productions such as the 2005Mitsubishi Eclipsead campaign,cite webFull Company Historyhttp://www.taikoproject.com/01/TAIKOPROJECT18 August 2013and in events such as the 2009Academy Awardsand 2011Grammy Awards.cite webTaiko Project to Showcase Fresh Interpretation of Drumminghttp://www.skidmore.edu/news/2012/3373.phpSkidmore College18 August 20138 March 2012

From 2005 to 2006, theJapanese American National Museumheld an exhibition calledBig Drum: Taiko in the United States.cite webBig Drum: Taiko in the United Stateshttp://www.janm.org/exhibits/bigdrum/[[Japanese American National Museum]]7 November 2014The exhibition covered several topics related to taiko in the United States, such as the formation of performance groups, their construction using available materials, and social movements. Visitors were able to play smaller drums.sfnIzumi2006158–159
article.heading: Related cultural and social movements
article.paragraph: Certain peoples have used taiko to advance social or cultural movements, both within Japan and elsewhere in the world.
article.heading: Gender conventions
article.paragraph: Taiko performance has frequently been viewed as an art form dominated by men.bulleted listHono Taiko|journalLin|firstsfnBender2012144Historians of taiko argue that its performance comes from masculine traditions. Those who developed ensemble-style taiko in Japan were men,sfnBender2012144and through the influence of Ondekoza, the "ideal taiko player" was epitomized in images of the masculine peasant class,sfnBender2012144particularly through the character Muhmatsu in the 1958 filmRickshaw Man.sfnKonagaya2005150sfnBender2012144Masculine roots have also been attributed to "spectacular bodily performance"sfnKonagaya20072where women's bodies are judged as unable to meet the physical demands of playing.sfnBender2012145File:Taiko drummers near the Basilique du Sacr-Cur, Paris, France.jpgthumbStarting in the 1990s, there have been a greater or equal number of female performers in ''kumi-daiko'' compared to male performers.alt=A photograph of four women in a kumi-daiko group performing in Paris, France.Before the 1980s, it was uncommon for Japanese women to perform on traditional instruments, including taiko, as their participation had been systematically restricted.sfnBender2012144In Ondekoza and in the early performances of Kodo, women performed only dance routines either during or between taiko performances.sfnBender2012155Thereafter, female participation inkumi-daikostarted to rise dramatically, and by the 1990s, women equaled and possibly exceeded representation by men.sfnBender2012144While the proportion of women in taiko has become substantial, some have expressed concern that women still do not perform in the same roles as their male counterparts and that taiko performance continues to be a male-dominated profession.sfnBender2012145For instance, a member of Kodo was informed by the director of the group's apprentice program that women were permitted to play, but could only play "as women".sfnBender2012153Other women in the apprentice program recognized a gender disparity in performance roles, such as what pieces they were allowed to perform, or in physical terms based on a male standard.sfnBender2012154–155

Female taiko performance has also served as a response to gendered stereotypes of Japanese women as being quiet,sfnIzumi200137–39subservient, or afemme fatale.cite newsChanErinThey're Beating the Drum for Female Empowermenthttp://articles.latimes.com/2002/jul/15/local/me-taiko155 January 2014[[Los Angeles Times]]15 July 2002Through performance, some groups believe they are helping to redefine not only the role of women in taiko, but how women are perceived more generally.sfnWong200074
article.heading: Burakumin
article.paragraph: see alsoBurakuminThose involved in the construction of taiko are usually considered part of theburakumin, a marginalized minority class in Japanese society, particularly those working with leather or animal skins.sfnBender201236Prejudice against this class dates back to theTokugawa periodin terms of legal discrimination and treatment as social outcasts.sfnBender201237Although official discrimination ended with the Tokugawa era, theBurakumin#Social discriminationburakumin have continued to face social discrimination, such as scrutiny by employers or in marriage arrangements.cite newsPriestlyIanBreaking the silence on burakuminhttp://www.japantimes.co.jp/community/2009/01/20/issues/breaking-the-silence-on-burakumin-2/#.UnRAhhD3OwQ2 November 2013[[The Japan Times]]20 January 2009Drum makers have used their trade and success as a means to advocate for an end to discriminatory practices against their class.sfnBender201237

Thenihongo4Taiko Road人権太鼓ロード"Taiko Road of Human Rights", representing the contributions of burakumin, is found inNaniwa-ku, OsakaNaniwa WardinOsaka, home to a large proportion of burakumin.sfnBender201238Among other features, the road contains taiko-shaped benches representing their traditions in taiko manufacturing and leatherworking, and their impact on nationalnbspculture.sfnBender201244The road ends at theOsaka Human Rights Museum, which exhibits the history of systematic discrimination against the burakumin.The road and museum were developed in part due an advocacy campaign led by theBuraku Liberation Leagueand a taiko group of younger performers callednihongo4Taiko Ikari太鼓怒り"taiko rage".sfnBender201238
article.heading: North Americansansei
article.paragraph: Taiko performance was an important part of cultural development by third-generation Japanese residents of in North America, who are calledsansei.sfnIzumi2006159sfnYoon2001422DuringWorld War II, second-generation Japanese residents, calledniseifacedInternment of Japanese Americansinternment in the United StatesandJapanese Canadian internmentin Canadaon the basis of their race.sfnTerada200140–41sfnIzumi200141During and after the war, Japanese residents were discouraged from activities such as speaking Japanese or forming ethnic communities.sfnIzumi200141Subsequently, sansei could not engage in Japanese culture and instead were raised to assimilate into more normative activities.sfnTerada200141There were also prevailing stereotypes of Japanese people, which sansei sought to escape or subvert.sfnTerada200141TheUnited States civil rights movementof the 1960s influenced sansei to reexamine their heritage by engaging in Japanese culture in their communities; one such approach was through taiko performance.sfnIzumi200141sfnTerada200141Groups such as San Jose Taiko were organized to fulfill a need for solidarity and to have a medium to express their experiences as Japanese-Americans.sfnYoon2001424Later generations have adopted taiko in programs or workshops established by sansei; social scientist Hideyo Konagaya remarks that this attraction to taiko among other Japanese art forms may be due to its accessibility and energetic nature.sfnKonagaya2001117Konagaya has also argued that the resurgence of taiko in the United States and Japan are differently motivated: in Japan, performance was meant to represent the need to recapture sacred traditions, while in the United States it was meant to be an explicit representation of masculinity and power in Japanese-American men.sfnKonagaya2005140
article.heading: Notable performers and groups
article.paragraph: File:EitetsuHayashi2001-01.jpgthumbrightEitetsu Hayashiin at a 2001 concert in Tokyoalt=Black & white photograph of a solo performance by Eitetsu Hayashi.A number of performers and groups, including several early leaders, have been recognized for their contributions to taiko performance.Daihachi Oguchiwas best known for developingkumi-daikoperformance. Oguchi founded the firstkumi-daikogroup calledOsuwa Daikoin 1951, and facilitated the popularization of taiko performance groups in Japan.sfnBender201252

Seid Kobayashiis the leader of the Tokyo-based taiko groupOedo Sukeroku Taikoas of December 2014.sfnBender201259cite webPerforming Membershttp://www.oedosukerokutaiko.com/htm/memberprofile_top_e.htmlOedo Sukeroku Taiko11 December 2014Kobayashi founded the group in 1959 and was the first group to tour professionally.sfnBender201259Kobayashi is considered a master performer of taiko.cite journalElectronic Musician117–121995Polyphony Publishing Company52https://books.google.com/books?id181819338He is also known for asserting intellectual control of the group's performance style, which has had an impact on performance for many groups, particularly in North America.sfnWong200485

In 1969,nihongo4[[Den Tagayasu]]田耕Den TagayasufoundedOndekoza, a group well known for making taiko performance internationally visible and for its artistic contributions to the tradition.sfnBender201260Den was also known for developing a communal living and training facility for Ondekoza on Sado Island in Japan, which had a reputation for its intensity and broad education programs in folklore and music.sfnBender201268–70

Performers and groups beyond the early practitioners have also been noted.Eitetsu Hayashiis best known for his solo performance work.cite webEitetsu Hayashi – Japan's Premier Taiko Drummerhttp://www.katara.net/english/event/eitetsu-hayashi-japans-premier-taiko-drummer/KataraKatara Art Studios30 August 2013Hayashi joined Ondekoza when he was 19, and after parting from the group helped foundKodo (taiko group)Kodo, one of the best known and most influential taiko performance groups in the world.cite journalJapan Spotlight: Economy, Culture & History2006Japan Economic Foundation5254028278Hayashi soon left the group to begin a solo careerand has performed in venues such asCarnegie Hallin 1984, the first featured taiko performer there.sfnHoover201198sfnThornbury2013137He was awarded the 47th Education Minister's Art Encouragement Prize, a national award, in 1997 as well as the 8th Award for the Promotion of Traditional Japanese Culture from theJapan Arts Foundationin 2001.cite webEitetsu Hayashi Biographieshttp://www.sfiaf.org/eitetsu_hayashi_bioSan Francisco International Arts Festival18 January 2015

Seiichi Tanakais the founder of theSan Francisco Taiko Dojoand is regarded as the primary developer of taiko performance in the United States.sfnVarian201331sfnTusler2003127He was a recipient of a 2001National Heritage Fellowshipawarded by theNational Endowment for the Arts.

Tokyo Dagekidanhas performed worldwide, including at theNational Theater of Japan,cite webTokyo Dageki DanPerforming Arts Japanhttp://www.performingarts.jp/e/data_art/p-10386.htmlApril 16, 2015at the closing ceremonies of the1998 FIFA World Cupin France,and the 2014Festival Internacional Cervantinoin Mexico.cite newsÓscar Ricardo Muñoz CanoCautivan a casi mil personas los tambores del grupo japonés Tokyo Dageki DanEl SurAcapulcoOctober 27, 2014http://suracapulco.mx/archivos/220744April 16, 2015cite webTokyo Dageki DanTokyo Dageki Danhttp://www.dagekidan.com/info/%E3%83%97%E3%83%AD%E3%83%95%E3%82%A3%E3%83%BC%E3%83%AB/tokyo-dageki-dan/April 16, 2015cite newsMara GüerecaEl milenario Tokyo Dageki DanEl Siglo de DurangoOctober 15, 2014http://www.elsiglodedurango.com.mx/noticia/547843.el-milenario-tokyo-dageki-dan.htmlApril 16, 2015The group also appeared inKyoki no Sakura, a film produced byToei CompanyToei.
